TornadoAggregate: Accurate and Scalable Federated Learning
via the Ring-Based Architecture

Jin-woo Lee,1 Jaehoon Oh, 1 Sungsu Lim, 2 Se-Young Yun, 1 Jae-Gil Lee, 1
Abstract

Federated learning has emerged as a new paradigm of collaborative machine learning; however, many prior studies have used global aggregation along a star topology without much consideration of the communication scalability or the diurnal property relied on clientsâ€™ local time variety. In contrast, ring architecture can resolve the scalability issue and even satisfy the diurnal property by iterating nodes without an aggregation. Nevertheless, such ring-based algorithms can inherently suffer from the high-variance problem. To this end, we propose a novel algorithm called TornadoAggregate that improves both accuracy and scalability by facilitating the ring architecture. In particular, to improve the accuracy, we reformulate the loss minimization into a variance reduction problem and establish three principles to reduce variance: Ring-Aware Grouping, Small Ring, and Ring Chaining. Experimental results show that TornadoAggregate improved the test accuracy by up to 26.7%percent26.726.7\% and achieved near-linear scalability.

1 Introduction

Federated learningâ€‰(KonecË‡Ë‡c\check{\text{c}}ná»³ etÂ al. 2016a; McMahan etÂ al. 2017b) enables mobile devices to collaboratively learn a shared model while keeping all training data on the devices, thus avoiding data transfer to the cloud or central server. One of the main reasons for this recent boom in federated learning is that it does not compromise user privacy. In this framework, star architectureâ€‰(FigureÂ 1(a)), which involves a central parameter server aggregating and broadcasting locally learned models, has been most widely adopted in favor of its simple distributed parallelism. However, the star architecture can easily become a communication bottleneck and cannot take into account the diurnal property of federated learningâ€‰(McMahan etÂ al. 2017a; Eichner etÂ al. 2019), in which the global data distribution of clients significantly varies due to the difference in the clientsâ€™ local time.

Ring architectureâ€‰(FigureÂ 1(b)), in contrast, can resolve the scalability issue and even satisfy the diurnal property by iterating nodes without a central coordinator. In addition, it has the potential to improve accuracy through an unbiased estimation of conventional centralized learning at the expense of communication cost. Notably, Duan etÂ al. (2020) proposed a star architecture with ring-based groups, while Ding etÂ al. (2020) proposed a ring architecture with stars-based groups. Ghosh etÂ al. (2020) and Eichner etÂ al. (2019) proposed star-based and ring-based groups, respectively, without global communication. Other than the importance of addressing the problem, less has been addressed how a ring-based architecture should be developed from the perspective of both accuracy and scalability.

In this paper, we propose a novel TornadoAggregate algorithm that improves both accuracy and scalability by facilitating the ring architecture. To improve accuracy, in particular, TornadoAggregate aims at reducing the variance inherent in a ring iteration by considering three principles: ring-aware grouping, small ring, and ring chaining. Based on the ring-aware grouping principle, for the TornadoAggregate with a global ringâ€‰(FigureÂ 1(c)) and group ringsâ€‰(FigureÂ 1(d)), nodes are grouped such that it reduces the inter-group variance in the global ring and inter-node variance in each group ring, respectively; the number of groups is adjusted to satisfy the small ring principle, thus achieving the small variance; we introduce ring chaining technique to increase the batch size with high node utilization in a ring, leading to the reduced variance.

We confirmed that TornadoAggregate achieved a higher accuracy by up to 26.7%percent26.726.7\% and near-linear scalability.

2 Architectures of Federated Learning

We first briefly describe federated learning and then survey relevant architectures in terms of accuracy and scalability.

Flat Architecture

Flat represents an architecture without hierarchical composition that, in turn, includes STAR and RING architecture. STAR is the same as the canonical FedAvgâ€‰(McMahan etÂ al. 2017b) without node sampling, as defined by DefinitionÂ 1.

Theorem 1.

RING is an unbiased estimator of the centralized learning that learns a centralized model by assuming the federated datasets to be located at centralized storage.

Consensus Group Architecture

Consensus group represents an architecture with group hierarchy and global communication to reach a global consensus among groups, which, in turn, includes four architectural combinations: STAR-stars, STAR-rings, RING-stars, and RING-rings. Definition 3.

RING-rings extends STAR-stars by replacing the group and global aggregation with the group inter-node and global inter-group transfer, respectively.

Similar to RING, RING-rings is considered impractical in federated learning due to large number of nodes.

Pluralistic Group Architecture

Pluralistic group represents an architecture with group hierarchy and without global communication to develop more independent and specialized group models than the aforementioned consensus model, which leads to decreased non-IIDness, and consequently, improved accuracy. Representative pluralistic group includes stars and rings. Recently, starsâ€‰(Ghosh etÂ al. 2019, 2020; Xie etÂ al. 2020; Briggs etÂ al. 2020; Sattler, MÃ¼ller, and Samek 2020) has received great attention, which is defined by DefinitionÂ 7.

Definition 7.

stars is defined as STAR-stars without global aggregation. Unlike Eq.Â (4), wtk,isubscriptsuperscriptwkit{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{t} is not synchronized with wtsubscriptwt{\textbf{w}}_{t} and thus group communication rounds Ï„2subscriptÏ„2\uptau_{2} is not defined.

Definition 8.

Similar to DefinitionÂ 7, rings is defined as STAR-rings without global aggregation.

It is important to note that the growing popularity of pluralistic group architectures may be hype. According to TheoremÂ 2, stars may achieve lower accuracy than STAR.

Theorem 2.

The convergence bound O(Î´â€‹hâ€‹(Ï„)ğ›¿â„Ï„\delta h(\uptau)) of stars doesnâ€™t necessarily be better than O(Dâ€‹hâ€‹(Ï„)ğ·â„Ï„Dh(\uptau)) of STAR.

Lastly, as shown in TableÂ 1, rings can benefit from the low convergence bound as well as high scalability of O(|ğ’¢|ğ’¢\lvert\mathcal{G}\rvert).

3 Reformulation: Variance Reduction

As previously noted, ring-based architectures such as RING, STAR-rings, RING-stars, Ring-rings, and rings have great potential to improve both accuracy and scalability. However, the convergence analysis framework introduced in this study is mostly based on unbiasedness property to easily compare all of the architectures. To better understand architectures from the perspective of accuracy, the variance should also be further considered. To this end, based on TheoremÂ 3, we reformulate the problem of Eq.Â (1) to the variance reduction of ring-based architectures.

Theorem 3.

RING exhibits higher variance than the centralized learningâ€‰(unbiased estimator of RING from TheoremÂ 1).

4 Proposed Algorithm: TornadoAggregate

The ring-based federated learning under high variance issue looks similar to the continual learning under catastrophic forgettingâ€‰(Parisi etÂ al. 2019), but the former additionally involves partitioned data groups as well as data iteration along a ring. Considering the differences, we establish three principles to reduce variance.

  • â€¢

    Principle 1â€‰(Ring-Aware Grouping): For architectures with group rings, nodes should be clustered so that inter-node variance becomes low within a group. On the other hand, for architectures with a global ring, nodes should be IID grouped so that inter-group variance becomes low.

  • â€¢

    Principle 2â€‰(Small Ring): It is straightforward that, the smaller a ring, the lower its iteration variance.

  • â€¢

    Principle 3â€‰(Ring Chaining): A ring can have multiple iteration chainsâ€‰(Ding etÂ al. 2020), each of which iterates the same ring at a different starting node and thus learns an unbiased model different from each other. Multiple chains can reduce learning variance, which is attributed to the reduced variance from increased batch size.

Based on the abovementioned principles, we propose a novel ring-based algorithm called TornadoAggregate and derive two heuristics according to the architecture type. We refer to TornadoAggregate with RING-stars and STAR-rings as Tornado and Tornadoes, respectively. In particular, for the ring-aware grouping principle, Tornado and Tornadoes require nodes to be IID grouped and clustered, respectively; for the small ring principle, Tornado and Tornadoes require a small and large number of groups, respectively; for the ring chaining principle, both require a large number of chains.

As shown in Algorithm 1, Tornado takes the node set ğ’©ğ’©\mathcal{N} and the number of groups |ğ’¢|ğ’¢\lvert\mathcal{G}\rvert, chains Cğ¶C, epochs Ï„1subscriptÏ„1\uptau_{1}, and communication rounds Ï„2subscriptÏ„2\uptau_{2} as input and returns the final model wTsubscriptwT{\textbf{w}}_{T} as output. It begins by initializing all local models w0k,isubscriptsuperscriptwki0{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{0}, a randomly permuted inter-group ring [kl]delimited-[]subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘™[k_{l}], and group indices {ğ’©k}superscriptğ’©ğ‘˜\{\mathcal{N}^{k}\} via the IID node groupingâ€‰(Lines 1â€“3). Then, for each chain and each node, the local updates are performedâ€‰(Lines 5â€“8); each group model is learned by aggregating all local models every Ï„1subscriptÏ„1\uptau_{1} epochsâ€‰(Lines 9â€“10) and is transferred to all nodes in the next group knâ€‹eâ€‹xâ€‹tsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘›ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘¡k_{next} every Ï„1â€‹Ï„2subscriptÏ„1subscriptÏ„2\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2} stepsâ€‰(Lines 11â€“13). Overall, Lines 4â€“13 repeat for Tğ‘‡T steps.

Because Tornado and Tornadoes are inherently correlated, we defer the description of Tornadoes to AppendixÂ D.

5 Evaluation

Experimental Setting

Benchmark Datasets and Models

We used two official benchmark datasets and models provided by FedML.

  • â€¢

    FedShakespeare on RNN consists of 715 nodes with 16068 train and 2356 test examples. RNN is the same as the one proposed by McMahan etÂ al. (2017b).

  • â€¢

    MNIST on logistic regression consists of 1000 nodes with 10 classes of 61664 train and 7371 test examples.

Algorithms

In TableÂ 2, the proposed Tornado and Tornadoes are compared with five state-of-the-art algorithms in terms of group type and number of chains.

Results

FigureÂ 2 shows the test accuracy for FedShakespeare dataset. Tornadoes outperformed the state-of-the-art algorithms by up to 26.7%percent26.726.7\% and the next best groupâ€‰(Tornado, FedAvg, and HierFAVG) by 4.4%percent4.44.4\% on average. The low performance of Tornado relative to Tornadoes is attributed to the communication interval; Tornado(RING-stars) takes Ï„1â€‹Ï„2subscriptÏ„1subscriptÏ„2\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2} steps for a global inter-group transfer in the RING, which is larger than Ï„1subscriptÏ„1\uptau_{1} steps of Tornadoesâ€‰(STAR-rings) for a group inter-node transfer in each ring, thus causing higher divergence. The poor performances of Astraea and MM-PSGD come from the high variance caused by the inappropriate node grouping and low chain utilization. Lastly, IFCA achieved the worst accuracy due to the difficulty of clustering FedShakespeare dataset, as explained by the small clustering cost reduction of only 4.3%percent4.34.3\%, in which case the relationship between FedAvg and IFCA is consistent with TheoremÂ 2.

FigureÂ 3 shows the communication scalability to the number of nodes ranging from 505050 to 500500500 for MNIST dataset. For each case, we measured the communication data size in bytes to reach the converged train accuracy of the case with 505050 nodesâ€‰(73%percent7373\% for FedAvg and 79%percent7979\% for Tornadoes) and showed the improvement relative to that case. Tornadoes achieved near-linear scalability, which is attributed to the superior communication scalability cost of STAR-rings.

6 Acknowledgements

This work was supported by Institute of Information & Communications Technology Planning & Evaluationâ€‰(IITP) grant funded by the Korea governmentâ€‰(MSIT) (No. 2020-0-00862, DB4DL: High-Usability and Performance In-Memory Distributed DBMS for Deep Learning).

7 Conclusion

In this paper, we provided a comprehensive survey of learning architectures in terms of accuracy and scalability. Our formal analysis led to the necessity of ring-based architecture and its inherent variance reduction problem. To this end, we proposed a novel ring-based algorithm TornadoAggregate that improves both scalability and accuracy by reducing variance in a ring iteration. Experimental results show that, compared with the state-of-the-art algorithms, TornadoAggregate improved the test accuracy by up to 26.7%percent26.726.7\% and achieved near-linear scalability. Overall, we believe that our novel ring-based algorithm has made important steps towards accurate and scalable federated learning.

Appendix B Communication Scalability

In this section, we provide an approach to measure communication scalability. Theorem 3.

RING exhibits higher variance than the centralized learningâ€‰(unbiased estimator of RING from TheoremÂ 1).

Appendix D TornadoAggregate Details

Algorithm 2 shows the overall procedure of Tornadoes that takes the node set ğ’©ğ’©\mathcal{N} and the number of groups |ğ’¢|ğ’¢\lvert\mathcal{G}\rvert, chains Cğ¶C, epochs Ï„1subscriptÏ„1\uptau_{1}, and communication rounds Ï„2subscriptÏ„2\uptau_{2} as input and returns the final model wTsubscriptwT{\textbf{w}}_{T} as output. It begins by initializing all local models w0k,isubscriptsuperscriptwki0{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{0}, a randomly permuted inter-node ring [ij]delimited-[]subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—[i_{j}], and group indices {ğ’©k}superscriptğ’©ğ‘˜\{\mathcal{N}^{k}\} by clustering nodesâ€‰(Lines 1â€“3). Then, for each group and each chain of the group, the local updates are performed at the node iğ‘–iâ€‰(Lines 5â€“8); every Ï„1subscriptÏ„1\uptau_{1} epochs, each local model is transferred to the next node inâ€‹eâ€‹xâ€‹tsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘¡i_{next} within the same group kğ‘˜kâ€‰(Lines 9â€“11); every Ï„1â€‹Ï„2subscriptÏ„1subscriptÏ„2\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2} steps, the global model is learned by aggregating all local models and then broadcasts back to all nodesâ€‰(Lines 12â€“13). Overall, Lines 4â€“13 repeat for Tğ‘‡T steps.

We derive another heuristic of TornadoAggregate with rings architecture, called Tornado-rings, which is the same as Tornadoes without the global aggregation to develop a independent and specialized model for each group, i.e., Lines 12â€“13 of Algorithm 2 are not executed for Tornado-rings. We note that, for the stars and rings, the test performance are measured with the group model of each independent group.

Algorithm 3 shows the two grouping schemes: Group_By_IID and Cluster. Both functions define their own association cost CostAsubscriptCostğ´\textsc{Cost}_{A} and update cost CostUsubscriptCostğ‘ˆ\textsc{Cost}_{U} and, in turn, call Group function with the defined costs. The costs are based on the EMDâ€‰(earth mover distance) that can approximately model the learning divergences, as proposed by Zhao etÂ al. (2018), which can be expressed as Eq.Â (32). In Group_By_IID functionâ€‰(Lines 1â€“4), a group data distribution ğ’Ÿk,isuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘–\mathcal{D}^{k,i} is compared with the global dataset ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} to improve the group-to-global divergence Î”Î”\Delta of Eq.Â (6), while in Cluster functionâ€‰(Lines 6â€“9), a local data distribution ğ’Ÿk,isuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘–\mathcal{D}^{k,i} is compared with a group data distribution ğ’Ÿksuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}^{k} to improve the local-to-group divergence Î´ğ›¿\delta of Eq.Â (6). It should be noted that for the CostUsubscriptCostğ‘ˆ\textsc{Cost}_{U} of Group_By_IID function, we had no choice but to use ğ’Ÿk,isuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘–\mathcal{D}^{k,i} instead of ğ’Ÿksuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}^{k} because a cost related to a node should be returned to determine a new medoid node.

EMDâ€‹(ğ’Ÿ1,ğ’Ÿ2)EMDsubscriptğ’Ÿ1subscriptğ’Ÿ2\displaystyle\textsc{EMD}\lparen\mathcal{D}_{1},\mathcal{D}_{2}\rparen (32)
â‰œâˆ‘âˆ€câ€‹lâ€‹aâ€‹sâ€‹s|â„™â€‹(yj=câ€‹lâ€‹aâ€‹sâ€‹s|jâˆˆğ’Ÿ1)âˆ’â„™â€‹(yj=câ€‹lâ€‹aâ€‹sâ€‹s|jâˆˆğ’Ÿ2)|â‰œabsentsubscriptfor-allğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘ â„™subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—conditionalğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘—subscriptğ’Ÿ1â„™subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—conditionalğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘—subscriptğ’Ÿ2\displaystyle\triangleq\sum_{\forall class}{\lvert\mathbb{P}\lparen y_{j}=class|j\in\mathcal{D}_{1}\rparen-\mathbb{P}\lparen y_{j}=class|j\in\mathcal{D}_{2}\rparen\rvert}

The Group function aims at finding subsets of node indexes for all groups {ğ’©k}k=1â€‹â€¦â€‹|ğ’¢|subscriptsuperscriptğ’©ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1â€¦ğ’¢\{\mathcal{N}^{k}\}_{k=1\ldots\lvert\mathcal{G}\rvert} such that it reduces the defined costs to the extent possible. For this purpose, it begins by selecting random medoid nodes ğ’©msubscriptğ’©ğ‘š\mathcal{N}_{m} of size |ğ’¢|ğ’¢\lvert\mathcal{G}\rvertâ€‰(Line 12). Then, it iteratively updates z by minimizing CostAsubscriptCostğ´\textsc{Cost}_{A} for all nodes and CostUsubscriptCostğ‘ˆ\textsc{Cost}_{U} for all groups until the cost is steadyâ€‰(Lines 14â€“16).

Appendix E Supplementary Evaluation

Experimental Setting

Configuration

We used FedMLâ€‰(He etÂ al. 2020), one of the most widely used simulation frameworks for federated learning, on PyTorch 1.6.0 to extensively evaluate the performance of various datasets, models, and algorithms.

Parameters

The parameters for both FedShakespeare on RNN and MNIST on logistic regression benchmarks followed those suggested by FedML. The benchmarks used SGDâ€‰(Stochastic Gradient Descent) optimizer with the learning rate of 0.03. In addition, we randomly sampled 100 nodes for both train and test phase, out of 715 nodes for FedShakespeare and 1000 nodes for MNIST.

TableÂ 4 shows the parameters used for each algorithm. In particular, for the group size, we applied the aforementioned small ring principle to all algorithms such that the group size of an algorithm with IID node grouping, random grouping, and node clustering is set to 2, 5, and 10, respectively, where 10 is considered a reasonably large value for the group size; for the number of chains, we applied the ring chaining principle to the proposed TornadoAggregate heuristics such that the number of chains is set to the number of groups, which is the maximum value by definition; for the communication interval, we firstly determined the product of Ï„1subscriptÏ„1\uptau_{1} and Ï„2subscriptÏ„2\uptau_{2} of HierFAVG to be equal to Ï„Ï„\uptau of FedAVG so that HierFAVG can improve accuracy by sacrificing little communication cost, as suggested by Liu etÂ al. (2020), and then we set the same parameters as HierFAVG for the rest of algorithms.

Additional Results

FigureÂ 5 shows the train loss and accuracy of nine algorithms on FedShakespeare dataset. Even though HierFAVG seemingly outrun the others, compared with the test accuracy of HierFAVG in FigureÂ 2, we can infer that it overfit towards the training dataset. Similar to the aforementioned results of IFCA, Tornado-rings performed bad because of the small reduction of clustering cost, defined in AlgorithmÂ 3, for FedShakespeare dataset, as shown in TableÂ 3. Low accuracy of SemiCyclic algorithm can be attributed to the low data utilization with low number of active nodes, which is also pointed out by Ding etÂ al. (2020).

FigureÂ 6 shows the train loss and accuracy of all algorithms on MNIST dataset. Interestingly, in contrast to the results for FedShakespeare dataset, Tornado-rings significantly outperformed the others except for closely following IFCA. The reason why the worst performers became the best performers can also be attributed to the large reduction clustering cost, as shown in TableÂ 3. To strike the balance between the two extremes, we leave Tornado-rings as our future work. Aside from Tornado-rings and IFCA, Tornadoes outperformed the others and the rest of algorithms exhibited the similar performance trend to that from FedShakespeare.

Appendix F Future Directions

We consider the following works orthogonal to our work, which can thus be easily extended to by TornadoAggregate.

  • â€¢

    Communication Reduction Techniques: This category includes quantizationâ€‰(KonecË‡Ë‡c\check{\text{c}}ná»³ etÂ al. 2016a, b), compressionâ€‰(Sattler etÂ al. 2019), or dropoutâ€‰(Caldas etÂ al. 2018).

  • â€¢

    Communication-Aware Learning: This category includes adaptive communication intervalâ€‰(Wang etÂ al. 2019b), communication-constrained learningâ€‰(Nishio and Yonetani 2019; Yoshida etÂ al. 2019), or multi-objective optimization of learning error and communicationâ€‰(Zhu and Jin 2019).

  • â€¢

    Global-Information Sharing: This category includes sharing a subset of global IID data samplesâ€‰(Zhao etÂ al. 2018; Yoshida etÂ al. 2019), sharing a subset of global data features to scale up the feature-related parameters of a local optimizerâ€‰(KonecË‡Ë‡c\check{\text{c}}ná»³ etÂ al. 2016a), or sharing a generative model that can produce an augmented IID datasetâ€‰(Smith etÂ al. 2017; Jeong etÂ al. 2018).

On the other hand, we aim at improving TornadoAggregate in the following directions.

  • â€¢

    Client Sampling: Client sampling techniquesâ€‰(McMahan etÂ al. 2017b; Sahu etÂ al. 2018; Li etÂ al. 2020) introduce a different variance aspect from those handled in this study.

  • â€¢

    Peer-to-Peer Learning: Other than the star and ring architectures, peer-to-peerâ€‰(P2P) federated learningâ€‰(Wang etÂ al. 2019a; HegedÅ±s, Danner, and Jelasity 2019; Wang etÂ al. 2019a) should also be considered.

  • â€¢

    Transfer Learning: In all synchronizations, model parameters are set to the previously learned model parameters, but we can also consider transferring parameters between different types of modelsâ€‰(Jeong etÂ al. 2018; Li and Wang 2019; He, Avestimehr, and Annavaram 2020).

  • â€¢

    Continual Learning: We can extend TornadoAggregate to the novel techniques in the field of continual learning, such as weight decompositionâ€‰(Yoon etÂ al. 2020) or loss regularizationâ€‰(Shoham etÂ al. 2019).

  • â€¢

    Algorithm Optimization: Other than EMD of Eq.Â (32), IIDness can also be quantified by loss divergenceâ€‰(Li etÂ al. 2020), gradient divergenceâ€‰(Wang etÂ al. 2019b), or weight divergenceâ€‰(Zhao etÂ al. 2018).
